context.text: And so I think it is fair to say that the Congress that enacted section 1983 would have regarded as remarkable the suggestion that any legislator at any level of Government could be held liable for actions of the sort in this case.

context.text: Well, in Justice Breyer's hypothetical, you and he seemed readily to agree that we can just look at this as a delegation problem.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: From the taxpayer's standpoint, this was a law that's been cancelled, and the taxpayer has an expectation the law's not going to be cancelled unless both Houses of Congress agree on it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Delegation is not just a subset of this larger problem, it seems to me.

Clinton v. City of New York.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Clinton v. City of New York.case_name: Clinton v. City of New York
Clinton v. City of New York.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 1998

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: From the taxpayer's standpoint, this was a law that's been cancelled, and the taxpayer has an expectation the law's not going to be cancelled unless both Houses of Congress agree on it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Delegation is not just a subset of this larger problem, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I don't think that larger problem goes away with Justice Breyer's hypothetical.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I didn't mean to suggest that it would.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I... there are two different bases for constitutional challenge.

Clinton v. City of New York.speaker: Justice Souter
Clinton v. City of New York.case_name: Clinton v. City of New York
Clinton v. City of New York.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 1998

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What is the constitutional distinction between what you call law-making and law-repealing?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There isn't any.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --Between law-making and law--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In Justice Ginsburg's example an appeal is being effected, and that is law-making.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --If Congress... there is... it is not our contention that a repeal of a law can be effectuated by any means other than those specified in Article I.--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: It is our contention, Justice Souter, that when Congress passes a law that contains two spending or taxing or tax cut provisions and says to the President, with whatever principles or not, you may choose which one of these to execute and which one not to, the President is exercising a discretionary authority that Congress has given him, and if they've given him sufficient intelligible principles, it's constitutional.

Clinton v. City of New York.speaker: Justice Scalia
Clinton v. City of New York.case_name: Clinton v. City of New York
Clinton v. City of New York.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 27, 1998

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --He has 5 days after he signs the bill, which would give him a maximum of 10 days.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Now, in the context of the... in the regime of the Budget Enforcement Act and Gramm-Rudman-Hollings, where OMB and CBO are required to make daily... weekly, if not daily calculations about where we are in terms of the budget baseline and the spending caps, there is a very important purpose to be served by requiring the President to decide yes or no, whether or not a particular item will be cancelled, and then to give the Congress the authority, particularly with respect to annual appropriations bills, to try and file... to enact, consider and enact a disapproval bill.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I mean, the irony of the--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: General Waxman, would you give... I'm coming back to Justice Breyer's question.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Would you give me something a little more... that I can sink my teeth into?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You've told me what these things that the President cancels cannot be.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: I think that the other provisions, the (a)(6) provision in particular, which this Court will address tomorrow in the Geiger case, is a provision which is generally applicable, essentially, among other things, to all torts, and it sets a standard which says wilful and... a debt for wilful and malicious injury.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: That has been interpreted reasonably, we think, to include punitive damages, to include other penalty sums, to include consequential damages, to include contractually arranged for attorney's fees, and is a reasonable and uniform way of dealing with what I'll call damages and consequential payments that are owed.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: Our--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Your answer to Justice O'Connor, it seems to me, follows easily from the answer you gave me.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I think attorney's fees are even further removed--

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: There is a one sentence reference that talks about the change being stylistic.
All right.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: Words to that--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If there is no reason, then... and if the language permits, as Justice O'Connor pointed out before, why shouldn't we read this exactly the same as it's always been read in the history, i.e., liability on the claim.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They're talking about a claim.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In other words, they're talking about a judgment, i.e. they're talking about what is normally in a bankruptcy proceeding a piece of paper.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: It's debt for a thing versus debt for an act.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: (a)(4), (a)(6), (a)(9), others of the provisions, use the construction debt for wilful and malicious injury, debt for fraud by a fiduciary... that construction, and I think it's quite reasonable, has been found to result in all of the damages for that act being found nondischargeable.

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: The construction that says debt for money, or debt for property, is a debt for the property, and that's our position.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Mr. Ayer, following up on Justice O'Connor's thought, is it not true... you looked at the issue much more carefully when you... before you filed your merits brief, of course, and are backing away from the footnote, but doesn't the footnote express what the treatise writers thought the law was?

context.speaker: Donald B. Ayer
context.text: I think that the prior version of Collier's took that position.
Yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the case that said all that is?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: In re Danns made the distinction between those.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: Now, in addition to that we have the--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I'm not sure how Danns helps you, because in Danns it was just the first part of Justice Breyer's hypothetical, as I recall the case, the $20,000 and the $30,000, and they said that the $20,000 that was obtained by fraud, that is nondischargeable, not the 30, or am I misreading the case?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: --No, Your Honor is misreading... is not misreading the case, but the... Danns did not involve the imposition of a trebling punitive factor, but the... what Danns did hold is that the statutes permitted the discharge of that portion of the debt which was not obtained by fraud.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So that the debt is severable for purpose of applying the dischargeability provisions, which is what the petitioner is saying, or am I misstating?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: I respectfully think that Your Honor is.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: We both agree that the statute... I believe we both agree that the statute permits a severing of that obtained legally and that obtained by fraud.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: The question is, does the statute in addition prohibit the imposition of treble damages or other penalties or punitive damages based on the amount obtained by fraud, which in Your Honor's hypothetical would be the $20,000.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Am I correct that in your answer to Justice Breyer's question you were assuming that debt or claim and money are synonymous, but it seems to me that under the statute they're not synonymous.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There are certain debts or claims, and those debts or claims may to some extent represent money obtained, so that if you recognize the distinction between claim on the one hand and the money that may or may not be represented by that claim on the other hand, you would have to answer differently, wouldn't you?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: Well, I'm not sure I'm following--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In some cases the object is the wrongful act.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: In other cases, it is what you are asking for by reason of the wrongful act.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: I think as a matter of grammar that's a possible interpretation, but to reach that conclusion, Your Honor would have to assume that in 1984 Congress intended to change what was I believe concededly the... at least the majority position that punitive damages under (a)(2) were not dischargeable.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But wasn't the prior law in exactly the form that Justice Scalia used as his contrast?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Wasn't the operative phrase in the prior law debt for obtaining, as opposed to debt for money obtained by?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that correct?

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: The discussion, what little there was, about consumer debt and bankruptcy show that Congress was concerned about curtailing debtor abuse.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Diebold
context.text: You would have to conclude, in order to rule in favor of the petitioner, that what Congress did in 1984 was stop and say, okay, but let's give a break to fraudulent debtors and reduce their liability and I don't think that under the legislative history of this statute that that's what Congress intended to do.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, there isn't any legislative... may I just ask this one question.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We've talked about a hypothetical in which the debt would be... Justice Breyer's $50,000, the $20,000 of it was obtained by fraud and that you're only talking about the consequence of that $20,000.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Are there any real live cases out there that you can cite that present situations similar to that hypothetical?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: This one doesn't.

context.speaker: Terence J. Cassidy
context.text: Correct.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And there's a second category where they behave in ways that shock the conscience.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That's a second category, not the first.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Then there's possibly a third category that Justice Ginsburg mentioned where you could have conduct, perhaps it's rare, but someone who's not a policeman, someone who doesn't behave in a way that shocks the conscience, but nonetheless either negligently, recklessly, or intentionally deprives a person of his life.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, that might be covered by the Fourteenth Amendment, mightn't it?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, at least where someone intentionally deprives a person of his life.

context.speaker: Paul J. Hedlund
context.text: --Well, I think there is... that's exactly the point that's presented here, and I would like to make one more point when I say, about the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Paul J. Hedlund
context.text: The individual who is killed in this case represents almost an innocent bystander, because he's on the back of a motor cycle, but at the time that he was actually killed he was standing in the middle of the street, because he had stepped off the motor cycle.

context.speaker: Paul J. Hedlund
context.text: It had stopped, and it was stopped in response to--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, if you... if, as you say, you can persuade a jury that the police officer just did this intentionally, as Justice Scalia says, you will win under any standard.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But the Ninth Circuit didn't analyze it as if that were the case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It analyzed it as if it were gross negligence.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, it's all a cost-benefits analysis, isn't it, and I guess if the... you know... you can't really--

context.speaker: Paul J. Hedlund
context.text: --I... you know, I think, though... I think that the notion of the Fourteenth Amendment is that there are certain arbitrary procedures.

context.speaker: Paul J. Hedlund
context.text: When you pursue someone for no cause... there is... without sufficient justification, and you endanger so many people's lives, going over a blind hill at night--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, you have this big wind-up, but what's the answer to Justice Stevens' question?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What is the standard under the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We're talking about standards here.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Schember
context.text: Under the summary judgment rules the plaintiff has to come forward with tangible, admissible evidence creating a genuine issue for trial on that, and mere assertion by the plaintiff of, I don't think the defendant would have taken the action but for hostility to me.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Schember
context.text: That's not enough.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, what about the case in which the prisoner has in fact taken some action, as in this case in going to the press, which has resulted in embarrassment to the prison.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Take Justice Stevens' hypothetical otherwise.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The warden says, I know all of that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, he spoke to the press, it was embarrassing, but that's not the reason I did this.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Schember
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, the ordinary rule of summary judgment is that the... all factual issues are resolved against the moving party on a motion for summary judgment.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Schember
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And on a question of intent like this, that Justice Souter is posing, or... it seems to be very difficult under ordinary rules of summary judgment to get summary judgment for the defendant, where the defendant says, I acted on a proper motive.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I did not act on an improper motive.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But there are some things which would permit an inference.

context.speaker: John T. Montgomery
context.text: Absolutely, Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What was the notice?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What was the expectation that these present companies had that this would occur?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'm not sure... how you can be so categorical as to say that Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical presents no due process problem.

context.speaker: John T. Montgomery
context.text: I don't wish to be categorical as to every single company.

context.speaker: John T. Montgomery
context.text: There are certainly other companies that may have as applied complaints to present with respect to the application to them.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So what you are saying is the reasonable expectations that others have of what claims they have on your property that's controlling?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: I'm not saying it's controlling but there is a combination of expectations and if I may--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You are saying, aren't you, that the acts, the unilateral, in answer to Justice Stevens' question, that the unilateral acts of one party to the agreement can create a reasonable expectation when the other party says no.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How can that be a reasonable expect... source of reasonable expectation when on Justice Stevens' hypothesis it is disputed from the beginning?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Well, if I may, the other party did not say no.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: No.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: I'm not saying it's controlling but there is a combination of expectations and if I may--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You are saying, aren't you, that the acts, the unilateral, in answer to Justice Stevens' question, that the unilateral acts of one party to the agreement can create a reasonable expectation when the other party says no.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How can that be a reasonable expect... source of reasonable expectation when on Justice Stevens' hypothesis it is disputed from the beginning?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Well, if I may, the other party did not say no.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: The other party... the employers never said five years and then we are not funding a benefits plan.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: The $300 million deficit that was projected in these funds by 1993 was made up entirely by the companies that were parties to the 1988 collective bargaining agreement.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: This was another agreement that was due to expire in 1993.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: When Congress looked at this arrangement if there had been no new collective bargaining agreement, all of the retirees in this fund would have been out of luck.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Change Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical a little bit then... so you don't have to pay off all people against whom you..., you were in violation of equal pay but only those people who are now impecunious as a result of your failure to have done that in the past so it has the same future application as this statute.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Would that be okay?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Um--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Do we have any finding by Congress?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Beginning in 1974 it was expressed in the contract.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: There is no indication that that was a departure and in fact--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I think Justice Scalia asked did Congress make that finding.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --The Act itself doesn't contain the findings but in a due process challenge, the question is whether the facts on which Congress apparently based its action could reasonably be believed to be true.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: About a Takings challenge and even if there had been in a Takings case a congressional finding that this property belongs to the United States anyway and we are taking it for that reason.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Watts.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: Yes, absolutely.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. DuMont, would you explain again, because I don't understand it, how it's possible that you can come out with one response to Justice O'Connor's question, where it's a conspiracy charge but a different response where you're being prosecuted for simple distribution?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, it seems to me, if your answer is in simple distribution we're not going to let the judge do it, I don't see why it... why you can let the judge do it in the conspiracy thing, since the conspiracy statute refers to the distribution statute.

context.speaker: Edward C. DuMont
context.text: Well, it's not a constitutional question.

Faragher v. City of Boca Raton.case_name: Faragher v. City of Boca Raton

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: One example, for example, was in the Bouton v. BMW of North America case, out of the Third Circuit, where the... where the company had a strong policy against sexual harassment, communicated it broadly, that the plaintiff had herself used before.

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: What we're asking--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, you have just informed Justice Ginsburg that if the employer had had a strong policy, fully communicated, that it wouldn't make any difference.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Now, what position are you taking?

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: --I am taking the position, Your Honor, that, number one, in this case, there was no policy.

Faragher v. City of Boca Raton.speaker: Justice O'Connor
Faragher v. City of Boca Raton.case_name: Faragher v. City of Boca Raton
Faragher v. City of Boca Raton.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 25, 1998

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: --I am taking the position, Your Honor, that, number one, in this case, there was no policy.

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: Number two, that the existence of a policy is a strong mitigating factor against imposing liability.

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: But that, number three--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, then your answer to Justice Ginsburg was incorrect... it would make a difference if the employer had a policy--

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: --Oh, it would certainly--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: --and that would be an excuse, so there would not be strict liability?

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: If a--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, that's because he's not a direct supervisor, presumably.

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: --Yes, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I thought Justice O'Connor was asking for an example where there was a direct supervisor who would not be liable.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Exactly.

context.speaker: William R. Amlong
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, the... we can't envision every case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Can... can you say what... what harm do you do to the fabric of the law... and I'm not saying you don't... but what harm do you do if you say the... the policing of the environment, the policing of the work environment for a high level supervisor, is precisely analogous to hiring and firing in respect to a hirer?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And if you do the hiring wrong, even for personal motives, the company is liable because the hiring/firing decision is the company.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And if you do the policing of the environment wrong, your company is liable, because the policing of the environment is a company responsibility.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I think that's what Justice Stevens and everybody has been trying to get at... I think.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And... and you're saying, Well, that would be somewhat novel.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But there is an analogy, I take it, in the asbestos area.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: The commission concluded otherwise, and the commission is now propounding a rule which, if adopted--
--General Waxman, isn't it--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --would permit them to adhere to that insofar as AIPAC still has the same rules with respect to membership as it did at the time.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --But isn't it true that, if they follow the definition of membership that the D.C. Circuit has followed in the case Justice Ginsburg referred to, then these people would be members?

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: Well, I don't... I don't think that the... my problem with answering the question, Justice Stevens, is that the D.C. Circuit did not apply, as we understand it, a rule with respect to who was a member.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: The D.C. Circuit simply struck down the commission's prior rule, which required, as a bright line test, that no matter how many dues anybody paid, and no matter how affirmatively they tried to be a member--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: It is a very tricky--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: General Waxman, I understand your anxiety about standing, and that sounds perfectly sensible, but I... what I don't understand is why you don't have a second step and say, if you should decide standing, then send it back to the commission.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The commission doesn't know yet what its membership thing is, but when it gets its act together this case may well be moot as far as a political committee is concerned, so I certainly understand why you want to urge standing first.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What I don't understand is why you're not telling us, but if we're wrong about standing, this case should not be... the ultimate question in this case should not be reached because it might fold at the commission level on what Justice O'Connor said at the very first is a threshold question, a preliminary question.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: --I guess the reason is that if you hold... if you conclude that there's no standing in this case, the decision in the court below is vacated and, in fact, the commission is back on its own.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That I understand, but what I don't understand--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: This is an action between private parties for damages.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: At common law, when damages were not fixed, as they're not here, juries determined the amount of damages, whatever may have been the case with respect to civil penalties.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: In Tull, I think--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --I don't want to interrupt Justice Breyer's colloquy with you, but you're talking about two things.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You're talking about the identity of the recipient and the... whether or not the amount is fixed and it seems to me that the latter doesn't help you here, because Justice Breyer I think implied that the range of penalties that Congress sets under the Clean Water Act in Tull look very much like the range that it is setting here.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --The difference is that under Tull and the Clean Water Act the Court couldn't... wasn't provided with and didn't find any analogies in the 18th Century where there was a similar range and you got a jury.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: And the legislative history is shot through and through with the fact that what Congress wanted was what the independent commission it had appointed was... had suggested, which is that you change the procedures, you not employ specific content or viewpoint prohibitions, and to the extent you want things like decency to be considered, it be embedded in the subjective, aesthetic judgments about what's meritorious and excellent.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: General Waxman, I thought your first response to Justice Ginsburg's question was going to be, so what?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought that what you responded to Justice O'Connor was, the Government doesn't have to buy Mapplethorpe pictures to hang up itself, and so also when it funds the arts, it doesn't have to fund Mapplethorpe, and it can say we don't like Mapplethorpe.

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: I knew that that would... I knew you would support--

context.speaker: Seth P. Waxman
context.text: [Laughter]

National Endowment for the Arts v. Finle.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
National Endowment for the Arts v. Finle.case_name: National Endowment for the Arts v. Finley
National Endowment for the Arts v. Finle.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 31, 1998

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Would you not still make the argument that since the statute says something different from what they're doing, our First Amendment cases, which allow challenges of a much broader scope than in other fields, would enable your clients to say that they are being deterred from developing indecent artistic programs by the statute that's staring them in the face, even though today the agency has said, well, we're going to ignore it?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Isn't that your argument?

context.speaker: David D. Cole
context.text: --Well, that is... that is... we would make that claim, but we would also make the claim, Justice Scalia, that the Government itself took... has taken the position in this litigation that the statute is indeterminate, and no one can guess how the chairperson might implement the statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: If you take Justice... if you answer yes to Justice Scalia, then you're just sticking pins into yourself, basically.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You're saying that things are all right now, but if they really opened up on this thing, they might be worse later.

context.speaker: David D. Cole
context.text: No, I'm not saying that, Chief Justice Rehnquist.

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: I think the analysis would be essentially the same, although for slightly different reasons.

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: Fundamentally, the Due Process Clause is not violated in this instance because there is no underlying life, liberty, or property interest that's at stake.

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: That interest has been adequately safeguarded by the substantial protections that exist at the trial court level and certainly throughout the appeal process leading to the final conviction.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Klatt, are you then saying that what... there may be some process due, but whatever process due it has been allowed, or are you taking the position that due process, as distinguished from equal protection, your answer to Justice O'Connor, due process doesn't enter into it?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The examples that, was it Judge Nelson gave, were due process examples.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That is, arbitrary decisionmaking.

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Souter
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Does it follow from your argument that there is no due process implication to the provision of direct appeals in criminal cases, no due process implication in providing the cert process that we do?

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: I don't believe that does follow, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: Clemency and that power is very distinct from the processes that involve the judicial processes.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Oh, I will grant... I'll grant you that, but what I was picking up on was the statement you made ago in one of your answers, I guess, to Justice Kennedy, that the interest being protected had been protected in the underlying proceeding.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I thought your point was that when in the underlying criminal proceeding, for example, leading to conviction, these interests had been protected, and there was simply a constitutionally unnecessary further proceeding, whether it be appeal, or cert, or clemency in this case, that there was no application of due process to those superadded stages.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Maybe I misunderstood your argument.

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: --Some power, some delegation of power is absolute.

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: The veto power.

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: State--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Klatt, I thought that that was one of the arguments that you made, but in your first exchange with Justice O'Connor you said yes, there'd be an equal protection check, so I was thinking that your argument was kind of like a, what's labeled political question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: This is committed to another branch of Government, totally executive, judiciary, hands off.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But your immediate response was no, there is judicial review for constitutionality under the heading of equal protection, so I gathered from that answer that you weren't taking the answer that you are now giving, that this is just handsoff for the judiciary, it is entirely executive branch business.

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: The rule says that if you're within 45 days of an execution date and it hasn't been stayed, that's when the interview process and the formal review process goes forward, so there is a legitimate State interest--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And in this case there was a delay in filing the habeas petition, I take it.

context.speaker: William A. Klatt
context.text: --There was, and the timing problem in this case was created essentially by the respondent themselves for not getting the stay in a timely way.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But suppose, just to test the theory and to take Justice Breyer's question a little bit further, a State had a parallel track.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The minute the trial court proceedings were concluded the clemency proceedings started, and the Governor said, it's very important that you admit guilt, failure to admit guilt will be an inference against you, and this was a parallel process with the direct review.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Any problems with that?

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, let me read you a couple of sentences from Dumschat which strike me as being a little different than the way you interpret... the Court said we rejected the claim that a constitutional entitlement to release from a valid prison sentence exists independently of a right explicitly conferred by the State, and then it goes on to quote from Greenholtz.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: There is no constitutional or inherent right of a convicted person to be conditionally released before the expiration of a valid sentence.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, it seems to me that says that unless the State has created some sort of a liberty interest there isn't any.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Stevens in dissent, of course, felt differently.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: --Chief Justice Rehnquist, I agree with what you just read from Dumschat, and I think that what is important about it is that it does focus on the decision, and that's what this Court said there isn't an interest in.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: At the end of this process, as Justice Ginsburg noted, we are moving into the executive discretionary decisionmaking process, and there, the Court is right, but we are not looking at that end of it, and we're not looking at what the decision is.

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Breyer
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: --That's correct.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: It--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The analogy that I'm... sorry.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Were you... answer Justice Ginsburg.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: --I was just going to say, it's correct we would... for this Court right now the determination has to be whether within the parameters of what's before it, that we might possibly prevail on a set of facts that could be established on remand, and so what you suggested earlier, that we could go back and find that what has been provided is sufficient, is a very real possibility.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: It's certainly not what we believe, but it is possible, and it could happen.

Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.speaker: Justice Scalia
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.case_name: Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard
Ohio Adult Parole Authority v. Woodard.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 10, 1997

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Wouldn't every prisoner have that claim?

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: Well, Justice Scalia, I think it's part of the problem with that process, is that if a prisoner initiates the clemency process, if he exercises that State right we've talked to you about seeking clemency, then he's made some choices about where he wants to go and the statements he's making.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: But when he is subjected to a forced process at a time when he is still in litigation, those considerations aren't available to him.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I understand, but my... the point I'm making is, we can't solve the problem, as Justice Breyer suggests, by simply making sure that the proceeding here is held after the last habeas before the execution.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The problem's going to exist in noncapital cases perpetually.

context.speaker: S. Adele Shank
context.text: Justice Scalia, I must say that if it was a forced process at some time I think that perhaps the hypothetical you're proposing would have application to noncapital cases, but that's not the situation in Ohio.

Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.speaker: Justice Scalia
Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.case_name: Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierra Club
Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1998

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That is, that sort of decision would be final in a way that the suitability determination here is not.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That is, if land is designated as off limits for harvesting there's not some subsequent site specific decision as to whether timber will actually be harvested.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: I think, though, that to establish--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The difference is that in the case posited by Justice Ginsburg it is clear that no harvesting will occur.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --That's correct, and here it's--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Whereas here it is not clear that harvesting will occur.

Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.speaker: Justice Souter
Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.case_name: Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierra Club
Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1998

context.speaker: Frederick M. Gittes
context.text: Well, if no one claims to have wanted to open a station in one of the States that were barred from having a station, you're right, there would be no standing, but in light of someone like--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Even though it may be a very stupid policy.

context.speaker: Frederick M. Gittes
context.text: --Yes, Your Honor, but here we have a situation where the plan creates the injury.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, no, because the... it seems to me on the analogy with Justice Scalia's hypothesis the injury in your case occurs when the hiker goes to the tract to hike and can't hike in it, or finds that the timber company's saws are waiting to cut, so the injury is imminent.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that the analogy?

context.speaker: Frederick M. Gittes
context.text: Well, Your Honor, our complaint is not just with timber, it's with a wide range of activities, including roadwork, road reconstruction, and many of those--

Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.speaker: Justice Souter
Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.case_name: Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierra Club
Ohio Forestry Association, Inc. v. Sierr.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - FEBRUARY 25, 1998

context.speaker: Frederick M. Gittes
context.text: It only occurs at the plan level, and the administrative record is complete, and our other--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --Okay, but your argument is that if you challenge the point at which the one tree is going to be cut, you're going to have to bring all of these other things in.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You want to bring all of those other things in now.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The question is, when do you bring them in, and it seems to me it's not an objection to the ripeness suggestion that Justice Breyer made to say, well, we'll have to litigate a lot when we do.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's accept... that's a wash.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's going to be true whenever you litigate--

Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.case_name: Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, Inc.
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1997

context.speaker: Nicholas Canaday, III
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Nicholas Canaday, III
context.text: To answer your question, though, you asked earlier, Your Honor, is if the conduct was devoid of sexual connotations, or didn't involve grabbing Mr. Oncale's genitalia, or didn't involve use of a bar of soap in a shower, as this case did, then perhaps there would have to be showing of modus, or motive, or intent, or animus, independent of the facts.

context.speaker: Nicholas Canaday, III
context.text: But given that this man was singled out for sexual abuse by his supervisors, the component of sexuality as a component of... because of his sex is inherent in the fact pattern.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Well, take Justice Scalia's hypothesis that the hazing here did not involve genitals, but just very nasty treatment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, if you could show the supervisor, or whoever was the hazer, did not treat women the same way given the same circumstances, then I suppose you could make out a claim of discrimination.

context.speaker: Nicholas Canaday, III
context.text: Yes, sir.

Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.case_name: Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, Inc.
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1997

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Those are your two burdens, then.

context.speaker: Nicholas Canaday, III
context.text: --Right, and the manner in which members of the opposite gender are treated and the manner in which the employer may respond to--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But how could you show that for an all-male workforce?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: That's... you seem to be thinking that it's irrelevant that we don't have any comparison group, and yet you answered Justice Souter, yes, it is relevant.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Where you have an all-male workforce, how can we know how the... this... these gross people would have treated women, or how the employer would have reacted to it?

context.speaker: Nicholas Canaday, III
context.text: --Your Honor, it may well be relevant, but we do not concede that it's determinative.

Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.speaker: Justice Stevens
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.case_name: Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, Inc.
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1997

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: And when you... in the opposite gender harassment cases the courts, lower courts have been prepared to assume, as I think this Court's descriptions in Vinson and Harris have, that it is because of sex.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Now, that may--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: So it's a presumption?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Justice Souter used the kinder, gentler word of prima facie case.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But is there a presumption that this kind of conduct is discriminatory?

Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.case_name: Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, Inc.
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1997

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, but I'm talking about the statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I'm not--

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --But the words used, discriminate means treat differently, or a draw a distinction between, and the words chosen for the harassment of the woman are different from the words chosen of the harassment of the man, and specifically because of the recipient's--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Well then, Justice O'Connor's hypothetical, then, would not meet the statute because no words were chosen.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Each one is just patted on the fanny.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --And it is not... it is not... perhaps looked at in other ways, it's not facially sex-based.

Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.case_name: Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, Inc.
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1997

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --You could rely on the Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: He wrote it.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Reasoner, have you finished your answer to Justice O'Connor?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I have a question, but I... if you have more to say--

context.speaker: Harry M. Reasoner
context.text: If I could say this one word, or sentence, the Fifth Circuit is saying that discrimination because of sex was not intended to comprehend relationships between the same sex.

Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.speaker: Justice Breyer
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.case_name: Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, Inc.
Oncale v. Sundowner Offshore Services, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 03, 1997

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But it's not necessary to look at it as an expansion of the statute.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It seems to me that it's sufficient to look at the sexual harassment law as being in effect a kind of evidentiary gloss on the statute, that when this kind of conduct occurs, as Thoreau put it, you know, there's a trout in the milk.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We know what that means, and I don't see why we don't also draw an inference when the harassment is between the same sexes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It may in some instances be more difficult to draw it, but as Justice Scalia says, what is the theoretical basis for saying you can never draw that kind of an inference?

context.speaker: Harry M. Reasoner
context.text: --Well, you know, first I would say that there... the statute is solid.

context.speaker: Harry M. Reasoner
context.text: It does not create such an offense.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Congress didn't say, one way or another.

context.speaker: Barbara G. Haynie
context.text: I believe the phrase, may not waive, is tantamount to announce, or proclaiming void any waivers which do not comply with the Older Worker Benefit Protection Act for those rights secured under the ADEA.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But why?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why would Congress wanted to have done that, because what you're being told, I think, from Justice Scalia and others, is let's imagine... let's imagine that a... that we have 100,000 workers who are quitting, and each of them has a contract, and they all promise not to bring claims, and each of them is paid [dollars] 5,000 for that promise.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, very few of them will have real ADEA claims.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But it--

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --Indeed, we readily concede that it's an invalid waiver.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: It's just not void.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --It's essential to your case that she signed the piece of paper, and that the piece of paper has the effect that Justice Stevens has been positing in his question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The signature is not a mere incidental fact of history.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It has an operative effect.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: I mean, the principle of tender-back has been available for 200 years.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: There's not a shred of evidence anywhere--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but the statute hasn't been.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, we're in this position because we've got a fairly unequivocal-looking statute, and the fact that the common law may have operated without the hindrance of statute for 200 years leaves us, I think, exactly where Justice Stevens is.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --Well, no, but there have been principles by which one can void or declare unenforceable contracts for 200 years, and there has been a tender-back requirement that applies to that.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: But the tender-back--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Again--

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: I agree with that, because--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --In response to Justice Stevens' point that I still think we'd better get straight, if we're the trial court, you don't say that the suit cannot proceed because the money was not paid back.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You say the suit was not... cannot proceed because (a) the money was not paid back, and (b) that allows you to plead the waiver.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --That's correct.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Congress had a model it could follow in this context.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: It had not only a statute that describes the matter as void, it also had a decision of this Court that enforced that statute in a way that eliminated the tender-back requirement, and Congress didn't follow that model here.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But there's a very good reason.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It did not want to create the specter that Justice Breyer's example creates of creating everything void.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It just said it's void insofar as it affects this particular claim.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: But it doesn't--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, I--

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Which is the one I think that the question invited, was--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Well, let me put it to you squarely.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Do you... are you concerned about the things that Justice Breyer is concerned about?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --Of course.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: I think those are fundamental reasons why you would not interpret this language--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --which your client did not comply with.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --But... and I understand that, but then I go back to the Court's opinion in United States v. Texas, where it says, when Congress sits down and tries to modify the common law, we do not presume that Congress means to undo any broader than Congress states expressly in the language of the statute itself.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Therefore, it's perfectly sensible to me under United States v. Texas to say 626(f) would get her into court if there are no other legal impediments to going into court, but it doesn't go that extra step and offer her an opportunity to avoid a forfeiture, a forfeiture of her right that arises as an independent common law doctrine.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But if the common law in a State were not the unreasonable position that a may-not-waive provision leaves both sides powerless, so the contract is construed, as Justice Stevens suggested, to cover everything else that could be covered to dispose of anything the parties could dispose of, but just as though it weren't there, the thing that they can't dispose of, so the common law, let's, say, in New York or New Jersey was not as you described it to be in Louisiana, could we then say that for these kinds of claims the Age Discrimination Act is going to mean one thing in one State, another thing in another State, or that there will be the Federal common law so that you'd have the same rule in all the States?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: I think the farthest you can go with Federal common law is to deal with precisely how you analyze the precise waiver, because that comes from the statute, and if you have interstices within the application of 626(f), it seems to me those you would clearly fill in by reference to--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well now, in Hogue, which you say doesn't directly apply here because in FELA Congress said it's going to be void, but nonetheless at the end of the day in Hogue the Court said we're going to require an offset at the end of the day.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: --and does that partially meet your concern?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: Well, obviously, as between having an opportunity to get some money back at the end of the day or not, undoubtedly my client would prefer that alternative, but the truth is, what we seek to have vindicated here is the common law rule, recognized in all 50 States and as a matter of Federal common law, that you must come forward with the consideration at the outset of the litigation.

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: That--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Phillips, to come back to Justice Ginsburg's question, what if there were different rules in Louisiana and New York, would a suit in New York come out differently?

context.speaker: Carter G. Phillips
context.text: --If we're talking--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If New York did not--

Pennsylvania Bd. of Probation and Parole.case_name: Pennsylvania Bd. of Probation and Parole v. Scott
