context.speaker: D. Michael Fisher
context.text: Normally, the case for the parole board would be presented by a parole agent, not an attorney, not an attorney representing the parole board, but a parole agent who would give his version of the facts, his version of what the parolee has done while out on parole, and there's a vastly different give-and-take in the process of the parole hearing.

context.speaker: D. Michael Fisher
context.text: For instance, parolees generally testify, give testimony as to what they have done, and so it is a very informal, flexible proceeding, and that is why I believe it is important for a parole board to be able to get the benefit of all relevant evidence which goes to the question of whether or not that parolee should be allowed to stay in the community subject to the conditions or to be turned... to be sent back to jail, so that's why we would ask that the exclusionary rule not be extended to parole revocation proceedings.

context.speaker: D. Michael Fisher
context.text: I would like to get back to the issue involving the validity of the search.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In respect to that, could I ask you, the part that I found most difficult in respect to the question Justice O'Connor asked is on page 9a, in talking about the question of consent, the court cites a... an earlier case and says that there, I guess, if I'm reading it correctly, we concluded that the parolee's signing of a parole agreement giving the officer permission to conduct a warrantless search does not mean... and here they say two things.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And the first, it's either-or, and the either says, either that the parole officer can conduct a search at any time and for any reason, i.e., it does not consent to random searches, or that he relinquish his Fourth Amendment rights, so it sounds because of that either-or that the Court in Pennsylvania is holding that this consent is not a consent to random searches, and if that is so, how could we reach the issue of whether it is constitutionally permissible for a State to do what you want to do, which is to conduct random searches?

context.speaker: D. Michael Fisher
context.text: Justice Breyer, in the court's opinion in the Scott case, from which you read, we believe that a full reading of that opinion, and particularly their holding, makes it clear that they were interpreting what they believed to be a reasonable search, which was that a reasonable search required reasonable suspicion.

Pennsylvania Bd. of Probation and Parole.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Pennsylvania Bd. of Probation and Parole.case_name: Pennsylvania Bd. of Probation and Parole v. Scott
Pennsylvania Bd. of Probation and Parole.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 30, 1998

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I... institutional pressure I assume relates to performance and to merit.

context.speaker: Leonard N. Sosnov
context.text: --But performance and merit should be constrained by the Fourth Amendment, so I wouldn't call a good parole officer one who, because of institutional pressures and zeal at doing their job and protecting themselves from possible repercussions if somebody messes up on parole, I would say that's not a good parole officer who violates the Constitution.

context.speaker: Leonard N. Sosnov
context.text: What it shows us, the institutional pressures--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But if being a good parole officer, as Justice Kennedy's question... means keeping your people out on parole rather than reincarcerating them, one would think that the institutional, pressures are in the opposite direction, not to return as many of the people in your charge to prison as possible, but to work with them to keep them out.

context.speaker: Leonard N. Sosnov
context.text: --Some work to keep them out, but the pressures to make sure that they're complying with parole regulations, we're talking about now the pressures as far as individuals who may go into somebody's home with no reasonable suspicion whatsoever.

context.speaker: Leonard N. Sosnov
context.text: We're not talking about parole agents who, in accordance with the reasoning of Griffin, only go in the homes where they have that low objective standard of reasonable suspicion.

Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v.speaker: Justice Scalia
Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v.case_name: Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v. Yeskey
Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 28, 1998

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We usually don't let the Justice Department say what our criminal laws mean by issuing regulations interpreting those criminal laws.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So why... why is that?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What's your problem, and I'm not saying you don't have one, because I hear this kind of problem quite a lot.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: What Justice O'Connor said, I thought was the case.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The law requires reasonable accommodation, and so you produce examples where it seems they're requiring unreasonable accommodation, so why don't you say to the court or whoever, reasonable is what it requires, what we're doing is reasonable, and if you're right, you can do it, and if you're wrong, you shouldn't do it?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm not saying it's that simple, but I want to know what the problem is.

Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v.case_name: Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v. Yeskey
Pennsylvania Department of Corrections v.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 28, 1998

context.speaker: Paul A. Tufano
context.text: --I do believe that when it comes to prison management, which is a fundamental aspect of our sovereignty, that Congress could have spoken a lot more clearly.

context.speaker: Paul A. Tufano
context.text: They could have put the word prisons or correctional facilities in their findings of areas where discrimination persists.

context.speaker: Paul A. Tufano
context.text: They might have--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But they didn't put in anything... they used all, as Justice O'Connor said.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: They used any.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: They used sweepingly encompassing, inclusive language, and you're saying they have to single out prisons, I take it--

context.speaker: Darrell E. Jordan
context.text: --Because, Mr. Chief Justice, the fact is that you have to look at the amount of money that comes from a client and the approximate length, in your good faith judgment, that it's going to be held in your account, without... you won't know, as a lawyer, what else is in that trust account.

context.speaker: Darrell E. Jordan
context.text: If you're in a firm, for instance, that it... that has several lawyers, each of whom handle, during the course of their practice, client funds, you may not know, and usually it's an accounting person that's going to decide and give you guidance about whether or not there's some opportunity there that can benefit a client, so... but as a lawyer, you're the one under the court's... the supreme court of Texas is, anyways, supervision, and told to determine whether in good faith you think it can be earned some benefit for a client, so that's the reason.

context.speaker: Darrell E. Jordan
context.text: The practical approach--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It doesn't mean, then, that in Justice Breyer's hypothesis, you would consider only whether one of the 100,000 dollars deposits could earn--

context.speaker: Darrell E. Jordan
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Darrell E. Jordan
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, generally speaking, if you had 100,000 dollars client fund there's probably some way you're going to be able to place it in a way that benefits a client.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, would this be a different case, do you think, if each person giving a lawyer money that might go into an IOLTA account were given a choice and asked to decide whether to agree with the IOLTA scheme or not?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: The difficulty with that option, Justice O'Connor, is that one of the important considerations in the IRS' approval of this and the revenue ruling 81-209 that we cite in our brief was that the client did not have control, because if the client has control as to... over whether the lawyer will deposit the money in the IOLTA account, then the income generated by that account, which goes to a charitable contribution, might be an assignment of income by the individual taxpayer, individual client, because the client would be exercising control over the disposition, so--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Oh, but you said a moment ago, and I thought correctly, that the client does, in fact, have that option.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: In answering Justice Scalia's question you said the client doesn't have to leave any money in a lawyer's trust account.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: Now, I--

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: It says nothing about other costs that someone other than the State might be incurring, so that, for example, in this particular case there will be costs that the attorney incurs for overhead, for setting up of the account, for all of these other things, yet the State of Texas does nothing to generate any of those funds.

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: This is not a case where somehow the State has pooled money.

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: This is pooling by the lawyer that, as Chief Justice Rehnquist indicated before, has always been going on.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Samp, can I... coming back to Justice Kennedy's escheat example, I was thinking that that differs from this in that the owner of a bank account that would be escheated has voluntarily let it go.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: He's abandoned it, in effect.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But then, maybe that's not true, because the contention has been made here that these people have an option, too, that they don't have to let the lawyer hold onto their money.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Not the Taking Clause, just normal property law.

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: In the--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: My worry was just the opposite of Justice Breyer's.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I worry that if we hold that there is no property interest here, that where this kind of a plan did not exist, the lawyer himself would be able to merge all clients' funds that could not individually make a profit and keep whatever interest comes.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm sure that that's not what the common law would normally provide, that that interest would be considered the property of the individual clients who ponied up the money.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, assume that's still the premise of this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Assume that's still the premise of this case.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: As Justice Ginsburg outlined it, why does the client have a reasonable investment-backed expectation of interest when we stipulate that he could never get that interest?

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: --I don't believe he has an investment-backed expectation, and that goes to the issue of whether there is a taking.

context.speaker: Richard A. Samp
context.text: He has not invested anything here.

Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.case_name: Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anzaresearch International, Inc.
Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 1997

context.speaker: Allen R. Snyder
context.text: Well, it is an act of infringement.

context.speaker: Allen R. Snyder
context.text: However, I think it's not totally independent in the sense that the language of 602 specifically made importation a violation of the distribution right under 106, so as we interpret the language, Congress was saying that we wish to make importation a separate type of violation of the distribution right.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But Mr. Snyder, if you're right about that, wouldn't it have been more logical to say, in the first part of 501(a), exclusive rights, section 106 through, including the right, the 602 right, instead of making it conjunctive, as... instead of making it separate?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Your argument would fit very well if Congress had said 602 belongs with 106A, but it makes it separate, and in that light, going back to Justice O'Connor's point about the representations this Nation has made, the Government isn't making them in the air.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It does point to this 501(a), and if that's a plausible reading, even if we don't owe Chevron deference, don't we owe some... don't we give some weight to the representations our Government has made to other Governments?

context.speaker: Allen R. Snyder
context.text: Well, first of all, Justice Ginsburg, 501 obviously is not the section that specifically was dealing with either the distribution right or the importation issue, and I think to determine Congress' intent, the first place that I would urge the Court to look would be the statutes directly on point, including 109, but I take your point that it could have been phrased in a different way.

Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.speaker: Justice Breyer
Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.case_name: Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anzaresearch International, Inc.
Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 1997

context.speaker: Allen R. Snyder
context.text: If the author divided up the worldwide rights in a certain way, where it's manufactured--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But if the contract is silent, your answer is the geography of manufacture is irrelevant.

context.speaker: Allen R. Snyder
context.text: --I think that's correct, but I... I'm not certain.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Am I right in my understanding of your answer to Justice Stevens that (1), (2), and (3) are exceptions from 602?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They all deal with, let's imagine a human being who comes to the border.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That human being who comes to the border got his book, for example, some way or other.

Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.speaker: Justice Breyer
Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.case_name: Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anzaresearch International, Inc.
Quality King Distributors, Inc. v. L'Anz.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 1997

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: They would like... the copyright holder, I take it, would like to have a vertically imposed territorial division, as would many manufacturers.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Normally we control that through the antitrust laws.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Sometimes you can do it, sometimes you can't.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Why, to repeat Justice O'Connor's question, would this antitrust issue of vertically imposed territorial restrictions suddenly be brought into the copyright law when it isn't brought into the trademark law or most other laws?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, wouldn't you have to have a fairly clear expression of congressional intent to find it, rather than the other way around?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, that's basically my underlying question in this case.

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: And I think there's every reason to believe that we do have the right figure here.

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: We have--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let me ask you this.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Going back to Justice Scalia's question, on your reading, what is served by having the modifier, as reasonable, in there at all, because on your reading once the figure has been recognized, that's it for all purposes, including future calculation.

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: --I think that avoids a potential question as to whether the lower cost or charges principle applies.

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: Under reasonable cost standards--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: One, if the Secretary made a longer period you wouldn't be contesting that the amount that the Secretary ultimately arrived at is an amount that is reasonable.

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: We would... yes.

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: We would say there needs to be uniformity, and whatever's the final determination for 1984, that is the amount that would be used for purposes of this average, that's correct.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Just following up on Justice Ginsburg's question, you would agree the agency could have repealed the 3-year window for examining the costs if it had chosen to do so by regulation?

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: Well, I don't think so in this case because of COBRA 9202(e).

context.speaker: Ronald N. Sutter
context.text: That clearly reflected Congress' intent that this would be established by 1987, and in any event--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: Then sometimes 2 and sometimes even 3 years later there's a notice of program reimbursement.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Now, the reason I... the reason the question interests me goes back to Justice Stevens' question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: If that's the way it works, at the time this statute was passed, would it not normally have been the case that all hospitals would at least have been paid in the first instance and, as an implication of that, their back-up, their figures, their costs would have been recognized in the first instance as reasonable, but they would, nonetheless, have been subject to a re-audit within 3 years.

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: You're correct in that the amount of money had been reimbursed, but you use the word recognized as having the same meaning--

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: --It could be... that could be one reading of the word recognized, but equally in fact we think a more persuasive reading of the word recognized is recognized by the statute, not determined by a fiscal intermediary.

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: Congress could have easily have said, come up with an amount previously reimbursed, or previously determined, or it could have said, previously determined under the Secretary's existing regulations, or determined under 1395oo, which refers to a fiscal intermediary's determination of the amount of reimbursement due.

context.speaker: Lisa S. Blatt
context.text: It just said, recognized as reasonable.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But it uses that phrase many other times, or at least several other times in the statute for the very purpose that Justice Souter is describing.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, I don't know that you can say that other language is more natural for this purpose in other places.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It doesn't say... it says, recognized under this chapter, this subchapter.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: --Like of luggage, or a stop of a person for questioning at the scene of a motor vehicle incident.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: Getting back to Whren, the Court was not there talking about a full custodial arrest.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: The Court was talking about a detention, a stop to investigate, which is not--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, you... but I thought you replied to Justice Ginsburg's question a few minutes ago that the Court has never distinguished between kinds of arrests, and now you're distinguishing between them.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: --Well, Whren was not an arrest, is what our point is.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: Whren did not rise to that level.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: Whren was a detention for--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, what is the significance of the term arrest in Fourth Amendment connotation?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: As Justice Scalia says, the Fourth Amendment doesn't talk about arrest.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: --It talks about unreasonable seizures of people.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: When somebody is arrested they're taken into custody.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: Excuse me, the Village can appeal if it loses after trial.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: There's no double jeopardy.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: It's in the nature of a fine.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Mr. Flaxman, when you responded to Justice Souter, Justice Souter's question about, you know, what's the harm, I thought you were going to say that the harm of allowing arrests for misdemeanors is that for the most minor of offenses somebody can be detained for 48 hours.

context.speaker: Kenneth N. Flaxman
context.text: That is--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's what you might have answered, anyway.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Yes, but if you're going to appeal the history, I think you've got the problem that was raised earlier.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: There is undoubted history that there could be arrests for civil offenses, but I think there is not undoubted history, and I think there is not any history that there could be arrests for civil or... for civil offenses without some written arrest warrant, whether you call it capias or some other term, and that's the issue here, not whether you can arrest or not.

context.speaker: David A. Strauss
context.text: Well, Justice Souter, before I assent to or disagree with that proposition I think neither case that was litigated about civil rights--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let's do it... I just want to work out the answer that you just gave to Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: David A. Strauss
context.text: --Mm-hmm.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I take it that you do not have any authority, know of any authority, traditionally, at common law, for arrest for a purely civil offense without some written process issued by a magistrate, i.e., like a capias.

Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana.case_name: Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana
Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 21, 1998

context.speaker: Charles L. Stern, Jr.
context.text: It's not a factual finding that a jury could make.

context.speaker: Charles L. Stern, Jr.
context.text: This isn't the kind of issue that's going to go to the jury.

context.speaker: Charles L. Stern, Jr.
context.text: It's essentially a legal characterization of a claim.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, if we take out the word factual in that last sentence, then Justice Scalia's explanation would be quite sufficient, would it not?

context.speaker: Charles L. Stern, Jr.
context.text: Well, it would be sufficient to this extent.

context.speaker: Charles L. Stern, Jr.
context.text: What it would be saying is that district courts have the authority to recharacterize claims if they believe that despite what... despite the characterization that the plaintiffs give to a claim it is, in fact, something else.

Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana.speaker: Justice Scalia
Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana.case_name: Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana
Rivet v. Regions Bank of Louisiana.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - JANUARY 21, 1998

context.speaker: Charles L. Stern, Jr.
context.text: So in terms of policy considerations I would suggest those at a minimum might say that if someone is seeking to foreclose on a mortgage that is the subject of a free and clear sale order in bankruptcy court, that at least can be recharacterized as an attempt to appeal from or seek to modify the bankruptcy court order.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Mr. Stern, could I ask you about Moitie again?

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why can't you explain the Moitie footnote... and I think this is somewhat the way the petitioner characterized it.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The Moitie footnote doesn't say anything about res judicata nor, for that matter, does Justice Brennan's dissent, to which you say the footnote must have been directed.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I don't believe he mentions res judicata even in the dissent, so we don't really know that the reason the Court is saying that this is an artful recasting of essential Federal law claims was because of the res judicata defense.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You're just assuming that.

context.speaker: Javier H. Rubinstein
context.text: --Let me answer that in two ways.

context.speaker: Javier H. Rubinstein
context.text: First of all, this Court has said that even where an open concession is made on an element, that that does not reduce the prosecution's burden of proof.

context.speaker: Javier H. Rubinstein
context.text: In fact, even where a defendant stipulates--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I was surprised to hear you concede the point that a... that Justice Souter began with that a trial is held, in criminal cases at least, only to resolve those issues that are joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, suppose the defendant comes in and says, I am pleading not guilty, Your Honor, but of course I committed the crime, does that mean you don't need a trial?

context.speaker: Javier H. Rubinstein
context.text: With the Court's permission, I'd like to reserve the balance of my time for rebuttal.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: --Mr. Rubinstein.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Let's go back to page 104 of the joint appendix.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: I'm having a similar problem, a problem similar to Justice Breyer.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: It says here at the bottom, what must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt is that the defendant knowingly possessed the item as charged.

context.speaker: Clarence Thomas
context.text: Now, what was that item, as charged?

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: --There is some ambiguity in this instruction.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: We have proceeded on the assumption that when this Court granted cert in this case it wanted the parties to brief the issues on the question presented, which is whether, if there is an omission of an element in the jury instructions, whether that--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I just am trying to find out what it is the Government says that's missing, instead of just being ambiguous.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Mr. Nuechterlein, isn't it true that the instruction that Justice O'Connor and Justice Breyer focus on related to count 3, and there wasn't a similar description with respect to--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: --Count 2.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Count 2.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: No, I think we have addressed this issue by giving petitioner the benefit of the doubt.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: This was an ambiguous instruction, and he did... if you read through the colloquy he did ask for what appeared to be the Staples element, and the district court did deny that request.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But that might be redundant, and certainly what Justice Thomas just read doesn't even seem ambiguous.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: He says, what must be proved beyond a reasonable doubt is that the defendant knowingly possessed... knowingly possessed the item as charged.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What was charged is that he possessed a 9-inch by 1-3/4 silencer.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: When there's a mandatory conclusive presumption, the jury comes in with a finding that that element was met pursuant to the presumption, and when you say certain conditions are met, the conditions are that that... either some other finding would have inevitably led to that, or that it have been admitted, but the jury would have come in with a finding, nonetheless.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: But I think that that finding, Justice Scalia, is an empty formalism, because the jury has been told that it must conclude that that element has been satisfied if it finds that the predicate element has been satisfied, so there is... from a juror's perspective there is absolutely no distinction between a mandatory conclusive presumption and the omission that occurred in this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Nuechterlein, can I ask you to comment on a rather broad point that is troubling me about this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It's been apparent from some of the questioning by Justice Thomas and Justice Breyer in particular that the Government elected not to make what was a fairly strong argument that the issue really isn't presented in this case, and this is a terribly important constitutional question affecting State trials all over the country, and this Court, too, and our normal practice is not to address constitutional questions unless absolutely necessary to resolve the case, and you failed in your opposition to the cert petition to tell us, to even make the argument that this... we didn't have to reach this question to decide this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Did you do that because you thought you might win a huge victory that would cover all these cases?

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: That is not it at all.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: When there's a mandatory conclusive presumption, the jury comes in with a finding that that element was met pursuant to the presumption, and when you say certain conditions are met, the conditions are that that... either some other finding would have inevitably led to that, or that it have been admitted, but the jury would have come in with a finding, nonetheless.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: But I think that that finding, Justice Scalia, is an empty formalism, because the jury has been told that it must conclude that that element has been satisfied if it finds that the predicate element has been satisfied, so there is... from a juror's perspective there is absolutely no distinction between a mandatory conclusive presumption and the omission that occurred in this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Nuechterlein, can I ask you to comment on a rather broad point that is troubling me about this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It's been apparent from some of the questioning by Justice Thomas and Justice Breyer in particular that the Government elected not to make what was a fairly strong argument that the issue really isn't presented in this case, and this is a terribly important constitutional question affecting State trials all over the country, and this Court, too, and our normal practice is not to address constitutional questions unless absolutely necessary to resolve the case, and you failed in your opposition to the cert petition to tell us, to even make the argument that this... we didn't have to reach this question to decide this case.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Did you do that because you thought you might win a huge victory that would cover all these cases?

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: That is not it at all.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: That wouldn't be subject to harmless error no matter how central the element if a person admits it.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: --Centrality is not an important part of our test.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: What is important is that the jury have... play a role in the determination of guilt or innocence, and if the jury does do that and finds every element of the offense correctly described under the appropriate burden of proof, then the district court's failure to instruct the jury on an element that the defendant admitted under oath can be harmless error.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, part of your discussion with Justice Breyer I think is fairly academic.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I mean, if there's an omission of a central part of the charge, whether you say it's never subject to harmless error review or whether you say it's never harmless under a harmless error review may be a nice question for academic discussion, but it comes out the same way.

context.speaker: Jonathan E. Nuechterlein
context.text: I think it does, and the... it is also the case that where the jury has not addressed an issue like that it may very well be that the error is not harmless.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: For example, from the legislative history, it... and from the reading of the statute, it makes it clear that not all prohibited transactions are covered, even if the agency receives--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, that... that... that's a bit tautological to say that not all prohibited transactions are covered.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Where... where in the statute do you find the language that would make it not applicable, say, to Justice Breyer's question?

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: I find it in... in the bribery portion of the statute that says that in order for it to be a violation, there has to be... it has to involve a transaction... business transaction or series of transaction of government, involving more than $5,000.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: That $5,000 figure is something that is carried through, throughout the statute, not only in the bribery provisions, but also in the theft and embezzlement provisions.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: I mean, we... we look at the language of the statute.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: And... and I think we also look at the... at the history of the statute, the legislative history, because it is unclear.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Convince my colleague, Justice Scalia, of that, would you?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: I will try.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: I will try.

context.speaker: Francisco J. Enriquez
context.text: If I could, another indication--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I just ask this?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I... I... I guess I didn't read it the same way Justice O'Connor did.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I thought the transaction was the conjugal visit, and that that had a value of over $5,000.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Isn't that what the court below relied on, the conjugal visit?

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: And I think, in many cases, in that situation, the... say, the government gives money to a local agency, in turn, to hand out money, the local agency won't be getting... won't be getting a deal for it.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: But I think, clearly, one thing that is within the statute is if someone bribes a... an agent of a local agency, you know, to send... send the grant money my way, rather than to somebody else.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: I think... so--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Wolfson, on Justice Scalia's example of opening a window, it would have to be worth $5,000, that... to... the market value of opening a window.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --That... that's right.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: And--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I... and I might add, on that very same point, that that's the way I think your indictment is... is better interpreted--

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --Well, I think that the... I think that the business of the jail could have been... the ongoing housing of Federal prisoners.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: But here, the... I mean, I think the--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, now, it seems to me, under Justice O'Connor's question, it's either one or the other.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's either the Federal program of prisoners or the conjugal visits.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --Well, the... the case was--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What... what is the government's position as to what the transaction is in this case?

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --Allowing the conjugal visits.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So, then, you're saying that the statute can't be interpreted, as Justice O'Connor suggested, so that the business or transaction is the program of... of keeping the prisoners?

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: I... I think it can't be applied that way in this case, because the... the statute requires a payment from the briber... you know, intending to be influenced--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: In most cases, it would make a lot more sense.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: The... the trans... the transaction is... let's suppose there was a State--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: What's the... what's the Federal grant transaction that's involved in--

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --The Federal grant--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --in Justice Ginsburg's hypothetical?

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --The Federal--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The transaction, you have told me, is the conjugal visit, which is not... is not related to the Federal grant.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --It is... what it says, it is the business or transaction of... of an... of an organization, agency or government.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: And it doesn't--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I'd like to get just one point clear.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Are... are you saying that, under this statute, business transaction or series of transactions can be, depending on the way the government charges in the indictment, either the business of keeping Federal prisoners that Justice Breyer asked about or the conjugal visit?

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: --I think it can.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: I think the business... I think--

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: But, as I... again, this has not been... we... we're bound by the theory which we took in a lower court, which was that the transaction is the... is the conjugal... is... was the contact visits that were allowed.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: Because that was basically an exercise of the... of the authority, or of the discretion, of the sheriff and the deputy sheriff of the county, who had the... whose job it was... whose official function it was to decide when and under what circumstances the door of the jail cell would be allowed open so that the... a prisoner could be allowed to see his family or... or whatever.

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: And that's how we viewed the... the transaction.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What is your response to Justice Kennedy's... at the end, he said, I think, if business... the word "business" fits pretty uneasily here, and the word "transaction" also fits pretty uneasily.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And it's a criminal statute?

context.speaker: Paul R. Q. Wolfson
context.text: I think that the... I think that there are situations where a word "business" could apply.

context.speaker: Mark W. Barnett
context.text: And in the second place, when we come to... to what the negotiator is telling Congress the Indians feel about 18, it gets one sentence, and one sentence only in the record.

context.speaker: Mark W. Barnett
context.text: And what he says is... with regard to 18, his comment is The Treaty of 1858 is not abrogated and the Indians shall get their annuities.

context.speaker: Mark W. Barnett
context.text: And so that suggests to me that... that if the Tribe really did think and believe that they were going to preserve their boundaries and their authority, number one, that's a glaring conflict with the cession and sum certain language; and, number two, is completely unsupported in the congressional and in the negotiating record.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: May I ask this question about Article I and... and also Justice Ginsburg's question of distinction between dis... disestablishment and... and diminishment.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: That when you say... when the sentence says they cede, and so forth and so on, their interest in and all the unalloted lands within the limits of the reservation... set apart... doesn't that kind of convey a message... I don't know... if you don't know the geography... that there's some un... unalloted lands within the limits of the reservation to which this agreement applies and there's additional land in the... in the reservation that's unaffected by this?

context.speaker: Mark W. Barnett
context.text: Well, I read that reference as a geographical reference.

South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.speaker: Justice Souter
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.case_name: South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 1997

context.speaker: Mark W. Barnett
context.text: And that is that the... the... the goal and the purpose of these cession and sum certain cases, the goal of Congress was to erase the boundaries--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Oh, I will grant you that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I don't think there's any... any doubt in... at least in my mind about that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But I take it that the... the... the construction that you are arguing for would work this way Let's take Justice Breyer's example and... and instead of having the four quadrants, A, B, C, and D, let's assume that there was 1 acre in quadrant D. And the Tribe had made a... an agreement with the United States, using the same language here, ceding the 1 acre.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I take it on your argument the entire reservation would be disestablished as a legal consequence of that; is that correct?

context.speaker: Mark W. Barnett
context.text: --I would... that would certainly be a more difficult case.

South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.speaker: Justice Kennedy

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: There are... there are city govern... town governments in each one of these towns.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Well, isn't this--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Under the--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --if... if you would win the case, just continuing with Justice Breyer's line of examination, would the Federal Government not then supplant the State with reference--

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: Only... only within the boundaries of the reservation and only with regard to Indian defendants in criminal cases.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --So in the nonIndian defendants, in the... in the ones... people, I'm thinking, who are not Indians, they have towns and there are some laws.

South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.speaker: Justice Souter
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.case_name: South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 1997

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So Federal law rather than State law would govern?

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: Because the Tribe had not gotten any authority to... to regulate landfills within the reservation.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And is the reason that State law would apply to the governance of the cities and towns in Justice Breyer's example, is the reason for that that there is no supplanting Federal law?

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: No.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: The reason is decisions by this Court, that provide for different kinds of jurisdiction over different people, whether Indians or nonIndians.

South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.case_name: South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 08, 1997

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: --It's not only rebutted, but it shifts... the burden of proof then shifts to the State or the people trying to abolish the reservation.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: And I don't think they've met that burden.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But don't you agree that there are various inferences that can be drawn, say, between Article XVIII and Article I and II, that it isn't just crystal clear?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And it seems to me there, as Justice Ginsburg says, if... if you... unless you're attacking what we said was the test in Solem, that... where you have a cession for a sum certain, there's an almost insurmountable presumption, you have to come up with something more than just one way of reading a treaty as opposed to somebody else's reading, either... either of which is plausible.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: But you also said in Solem that there must be substantial and compelling evidence in order to disestablish or diminish a reservation.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: And what I'm saying, Your Honor, is this That the... the evidence is not there.

South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.speaker: Justice Souter
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.case_name: South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: So that there were... there were no tribal lands retained in 1892?

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: Yes, there were.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: But--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, I thought... then I don't understand your answer to Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: --I must have misunderstood his question.

context.speaker: James G. Abourezk
context.text: But there are... there were tribal lands in 1894.

South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.speaker: Justice Breyer
South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe.case_name: South Dakota v. Yankton Sioux Tribe

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So, in other words, these towns that are upset... I don't understand they're upset, or maybe they shouldn't be upset, because nothing is going to change for them?

context.speaker: Barbara B. McDowell
context.text: That's our position, that things should not change--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Then why is it... I'm back at Justice Kennedy's point... why is it that there's some argument here about building a... some kind of thing in this... waste disposal or what it is... if the State law governs the same as it would if it were not within the reservation?

context.speaker: Barbara B. McDowell
context.text: --This was a... a particular issue of the EPA's authority to delegate primary supervision of landfills to the State.

context.speaker: Barbara B. McDowell
context.text: And under that permitting authority, the State excluded Indian reservations, as I understand it.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Was I... am I wrong about that?

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: --I... Your Honor, I am not sure about where the focus of it was, except that in the Eighth Circuit the focus was on the parole consequences as... and to the exclusion, I will concede, of later consequences such as sentence enhancement.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Let me ask you a different question, if I may.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It goes back to what Justice Breyer began with.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I take it you accept the fact that at a later parole revocation hearing, at least, you could indeed argue and present evidence to the effect that the underlying conduct that was assumed in this revocation in fact didn't take place.

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: Well, it's... I guess it depends on what we mean by in and of itself.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: No--

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: Consequences.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --What I mean by this is the following, and I think maybe Justice Kennedy means the same.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If you have a prior conviction and then you come up for sentencing again, that's it, you know.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You get a bump up.

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: --Or, Your Honor, when he is the victim in an automobile accident and has to testify--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that--

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: --to get his medical expenses paid.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --That invokes Justice Souter's earlier observation that at that point he says, look, this was an improper revocation, you go from there, and then you said that... I think that's when you said it was... Occam's razor applied, because this is more--

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: Parsimonious.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --I assume because this is more complex.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --I assume because this is more complex.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It seems to me it's much more... is Occam's razor a precedent we cited in this Court?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I haven't seen it recently.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But assuming that it is, it seems to me that Justice Souter's solution addresses that.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's much more simple to wait until there is a specific harm, and then talk about it, as opposed to saying that 1983 is available... or, pardon me, that habeas corpus is available for every parole revocation violation when the custody is terminated.

context.speaker: John W. Simon
context.text: Your Honor, I thought that the Court had crossed that bridge in Sibron, and my question is, if it... if Sibron is right on that point, that we shoot it out closer in time to the transactions and occurrences involved in the case, which is what the respondents normally want to do in collateral attacks, is litigate things closer in time while the witnesses are still alive, they're still around, the blood samples are fresh, what not, why doesn't it work when it cuts in the petitioner's favor?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: No... well, we... how can we say that if, in fact, in other cases we've said that a person who is no longer in custody can bring it?

context.speaker: James R. Layton
context.text: I think that Justice Breyer presents the problem.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yes, if one goes back to the... if one wants to analyze it by the statute, according to Justice Breyer, one would never have decided Carafas or Sibron the way they did.

context.speaker: James R. Layton
context.text: It's certainly possible to go to where Justice Thomas led in, I believe it's the Heck decision, and not have any of these problems, but we aren't there today, and today we're in the presence of the Lane decision that says that when the future consequences are discretionary, when they're speculative, when they require certain intervening steps before there's some kind of relief, that we aren't going to recognize that the case continues after custody in those situations.

context.speaker: James R. Layton
context.text: So the Court doesn't have to go nearly that far in order to reach the conclusion that it ought to reach today.

context.speaker: Anthony S. DiVincenzo
context.text: He could not charge another price.

context.speaker: Anthony S. DiVincenzo
context.text: If he did, it went to State Oil.

context.speaker: Anthony S. DiVincenzo
context.text: If he dropped below, he lost money.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: If... if I understand your response to Justice Scalia, it would be that lowering the price of the cheap grade will make him more money, but not for a year or two.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So we have to stay in business until it pays off.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And so, what we'll do is raise the high price even more, and that gives us the money necessary to stay in business until the low price pays off.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 96-871, State Oil Co. against. Khan will be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: It stands from a dispute concerning respondent's agreement with State Oil Company to lease and operate a gas station.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But even if there were mootness, after the 60-day period ran as a result of compliance there would still be entitlement to attorney's fees, would there not, because the mootness didn't come about until after the case was in court.

context.speaker: Sanford M. Stein
context.text: If the court were to retain jurisdiction after properly receiving it, then I assume the court could then address the question of anything within its jurisdiction, including whether or not the prevailing party was the plaintiff, the citizen organization in that case, and whether or not it should receive fees.

context.speaker: Sanford M. Stein
context.text: We do not have a problem with those issues after proper filing, meaning that there is a violation that is ongoing on the date that the complaint is filed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, you're putting in this phrase, retain jurisdiction, and I... maybe Justice Scalia thought you answered his question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I still... I'm still not sure of the answer to that question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Let's assume that after the 60 days has run, the suit is filed, then it's cured, then it comes before the judge, the judge says there's nothing more to do, I'm going to give no... I'm going to terminate my jurisdiction now, there's no necessity for me to issue some ongoing injunction, but I am going to award attorney's fees.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I don't understand why those two would be different, if you say, and he has never before attacked the determination that was just made in the Arizona State court that he is competent, that was just made last week.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Why isn't that not successive?

context.speaker: Bruce M. Ferg
context.text: It is successive because it goes ultimately to that very same sentence that was imposed upon him in the first place, and therefore he is coming a second time to in effect get a Federal court to say, you cannot execute this person.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is there any reason to think that Congress wanted the result that Justice Ginsburg is discussing?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, is there any reason to think that Congress somehow wanted to take this unusual set of claims that arise only, and can by their very nature arise only well after the trial itself, that have nothing to do with the trial, that have nothing to do with the appeals... it would be a claim, for example, saying we're going to torture someone to death, or I mean, you know, some frightful thing, think of some awful thing, and it could never have arisen before.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, is there any reason Congress would have wanted to bar habeas totally from such a claim?

context.speaker: Bruce M. Ferg
context.text: Well, I would suggest that it would not be capricious at all, because in effect what we're finding here is that t he individual is going to have virtually the same kind of review that he would have had without AEDPA, because competency is a factual matter, and for example in Demosthenes v. Baal and Maggio v. Fulford this Court made very clear that, even without AEDPA, there's a factual issue which the courts, the Federal courts must defer to, and so this Court on--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, that doesn't go to the jurisdiction of the Federal court ultimately to entertain the claim.

context.speaker: Bruce M. Ferg
context.text: --What I'm saying, though, is that it is consistent to say that this is an appropriate way to limit the kinds of issues that are going to come in front of the district court, which doesn't drastically--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But it doesn't... I have the same question as Justice Souter.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You have two cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: One case, all he does is bring a competency... a claim that he's incompetent to be executed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In case number 1 you're going to be able to hear the claim later.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Case number 2, you're not.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That just makes no sense.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
