context.text: If this money was from... laundered money, it was involved in some type of criminal enterprise.
Yes.

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: Or if it was money that was going out of the country not to pay taxes, to avoid payment of taxes, then it would be tainted money, an instrumentality, but--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What if, under Justice Scalia's hypothesis, the defendant in the firearm case took the stand and said, well, in my country it's perfectly legal to have a firearm, so I did it kind of for cultural reasons.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: --Well, it depends on whether it was lawful or not.

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: That is in the record.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --Did he prove that taxes had been paid on it?

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: The taxes had been paid on it, Your Honor, yes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Can you go back for a second, because I'm now concerned... Mr. Gornstein answered me and Justice Scalia picked up a point that I'd not focused on, which is that this is a mandatory forfeiture statute.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It says the defendant shall forfeit.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, I can understand a statute that says the convicted person in a case of robbery must pay a penalty up to 5 million dollars as well as prison, and then a person take 1 dollar, and the judge imposes 5 million dollars, and you say, well, that's way disproportionate, but the statute said may, and I think his point is here that the statute says shall, and so what Congress is saying here is, you shall.

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: If it's contraband, or proceeds from contraband, or if it fits into the historical standard as--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --But why is it that a metaphysical label then changes whether or not in fact it's excessive?

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: --I would agree with you, Your Honor, in that, because the legal fiction--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well then... then I think you have to answer Justice Scalia that you cannot--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --Right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Give me back the moonstone.

context.speaker: James E. Blatt
context.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You're quite right, it said shall forfeit.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Now, suppose because of that we have to look at the application case-by-case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Still I'm back to where Justice O'Connor started.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: It's very hard to believe that all we're going to do is in every single case start looking as to whether there's an abuse of discretion.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is there not some standard that you've come across that could catch the extreme cases that wouldn't involve an analysis case by case, instant by instance, of whether the judge somehow went a little wrong, or, in your view, do you have to conduct that under the Constitution?

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Once the Court has made the decision to extend the right in question to the States through the Fourteenth Amendment, that's correct.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They are coterminous in each case.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: They're coextensive, and the fundamental premise of the Murphy decision is that we do have cooperative federalism in this country when it comes to law enforcement, and it makes very little sense to say that once the States are no longer free to compel testimony under the Federal Constitution, that they may then operate together and achieve results that they couldn't achieve--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Can I ask you about that, because I was just testing out the linguistic argument, that's why I was... Justice Stevens made the point linguistically, but I have a practical question, which is why... how specifically would extension of the protection that you oppose interfere with Government law enforcement efforts?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: In particular, I'm thinking that it must be perhaps a fairly unusual case where, say, as here, the statute of limitations has run, 5 years, so there's no risk of domestic protection.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I'm guessing that in most cases anybody who can assert a Fifth Amendment privilege in respect to a foreign country probably could here, too, so I'm interested in... I'm raising that so you'll respond to the real practicality, how would extension really interfere with law enforcement efforts?

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: But that does not minimize the constitutional claim that we're advocating.

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: We're advocating that this Court recognize the individual liberties component as it was so eloquently explained in Murphy, and I submit to you that individual liberties component, if it is recognized, as being a very important component of the privilege.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, calling it an individual liberty doesn't make it any... doesn't change the wording of the Fifth Amendment, which is a privilege against self-incrimination, and I think... you know, worldwide, as Justice Ginsburg has suggested, that is not a universal... universally valued as highly as it is in this country.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So to call it individual liberty I think is perhaps an overstatement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It's something that is in our Constitution.

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice, that is so, but this Court has in a long line of cases since Murphy reiterated this liberty aspect and used very, very strong language in saying that the liberty aspect of the privilege is important.

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: It's not--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Of course, it's a liberty that he has while he's in this country.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If as Justice Kennedy suggested, a case in which the Government has two grounds for deportation, one that doesn't incriminate him and one that does, and say he's silent about the one that does but he gets deported on the other ground and he gets sent to Lithuania, and if Lithuania doesn't recognize this liberty, he would there be forced to testify against himself, wouldn't he?

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: --That may very well come to pass, Your Honor, but nevertheless, while he is here, and while he is subject to an Article III court, that Article III court ought not compel him to convict himself out of his own mouth, not here in this country.

context.speaker: Ivars Berzins
context.text: What happens in Lithuania, we can't control, but we can control--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: The interest of CPC and the interests of the subsidiary are identical.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: --If the legal... the legal standard we're espousing is that it is CPC that is actively managing the facility.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: If the question is whether the district court's findings that talk about CPC really mean that it is Ott that's taking the actions, in fact the court specifically talks about CPC itself, and we think that, and particularly the facts that are listed at pages 11 and 12 of our opening brief, underscore that it is the parent company that is operating the facility within the meaning of operate.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, but unless we get a situation like Williams, how do we avoid the problem that Justice Ginsburg said that she had in reading the findings?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How do we draw some metaphysical line between CPC as the operator and CPC simply getting the benefit of the influence which it undoubtedly has as a parent through the ownership of stock and through the frequently overlapping composition of the officers and directors?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: How do we draw that line when we don't have kind of an easy Williams example?

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: What Congress did in the Superfund law is look at the direct liability of the parent, which is really consistent with--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Well, I know that's what you're saying, but it gets us back to that same question of how you draw the line and whether the statute is, indeed, that clear.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: --Your Honor, we think that operate is, indeed, defined in a circular way, and we looked at the dictionary, but we think the Court can get some good guidance from the lender liability provisions adopted in the lender context, but which spell out a set of standards for how much activity and operation is necessary to meet the standard.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And under that definition, and under what I think is your answer to Justice Breyer, and I want to be very clear about this, it would be very rare that a corporation would be solely liable and not have some of its principal managers, operators, officers, also liable, is that not right?

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: It would not be... it would be very rare, Your Honor, because the ordinary corporation which is acting in a supervisory capacity through a subsidiary and not with active management would not be liable--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, forget parent and subsidiary.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, forget parent and subsidiary.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It's very unusual for a corporation to commit a tort by itself without some human actor.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: --Yes, and--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the human actor is a cotortfeasor, and I take it your answer to Justice Breyer was that by using the word, any person, in 9607(b), that the Congress would make all of the people in his hypothetical that were actively participating in the waste disposal personally liable.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: --We believe that that is correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: And even if they hire somebody?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No, no, but what they do is... yes, they--

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: --not in management.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --It says owner or operator.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Certainly Justice Breyer's people are operating the thing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I'm trying to assume facts that they are, you know.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I'm trying to assume facts such that these are the people... they're fairly low-level supervisors, and so forth, but it's a small dump, and what they do is, they turn shovels, they make all the decisions there, they decide what to bury, what not to bury, they dig... you understand what I'm driving at.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: For example, what I'm thinking of is, if CPC passed a resolution, or if its president said to Williams, consistently with the corporate resolution, Williams, go down there and make sure that they dump the waste in the sand immediately, you don't have to say that Williams is liable under those circumstances in order to get CPC liability as well as the subsidiary liability, do you?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You could respect the corporate form and still, in effect, get your... the result that you think is proper in this case?

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: --That's exactly correct, Your Honor, and we think that our theory is consistent with respecting the corporate form because it looks at what is the corporation doing for its own activities.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Right, but I thought in answer to Justice Breyer's question you were getting to the point where... of saying that whenever the employee of a corporation does the act which forms a part of the operation, that the employee is an operator and therefore liable regardless of whether the employee is acting as a maverick in relation to his corporate organization or whether he is doing exactly what his corporate organization told him to do, and now I think you're saying you're maybe not going that far.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: The test is participation in management.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: If there is a maverick employee who midnightdumps in the back 40, we would look at the activities of that particular person, but if the people are working for the corporation, following the orders of management, then we... it is the management and not the individual employees who would be liable.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: So--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: --So I think that you were saying that in any close corporation there would be shareholder liability.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: In fact, what the cases that look at shareholder liability really are taking people who are shareholders and chief executive officers and really are the active managers.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I'm referring to a family corporation, the kind Justice Breyer described, a one-person corporation, a closed corporation, very small group, where they're all involved in running the business.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: In all those cases your theory is, you would reach the people who are operating, the participants in those close corporations.

context.speaker: Lois J. Schiffer
context.text: We think that is what Congress intended by its definition of the term, operator, to assure that those who are responsible for the pollution are responsible for cleaning it up, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: In order to show that CPC operated this facility, you have to show that some employee of CPC did something that could be construed as operating this facility.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Granted.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: Now--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And if we can just stick with Justice Breyer's hypothetical a minute, because that's where we ended the argument--

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --would you agree that if three people were all actively involved in managing a facility, that they would all be operators?

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: We simply have a shareholder here that did nothing that could be construed as operating the facility.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: All of the employees of CPC--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Let me be sure I understand your position, Mr. Geller.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You take Justice Breyer's hypothetical and say yes, Mr. and Mrs. Smith and their son would be liable, if I understand your--

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: --If they were actually physically engaged in operating the facility, they would fall within the statute, I would think, but that's not--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --So that any employee of a corporation with a facility can be liable?

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: I'm not sure it changes anything, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: In fact, if you look at the derivation of this, this came into a House bill, H.R. 85, that only defined owner, and this was an exception to owner liability.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: When the bills were combined it was put in this way, but it's clear that what Congress was talking about here are people who hold security interests in States that would make them owners.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but it seems to me, as Justice Stevens indicates, that if management participation, which is what the Congress is interested in, is management participation, who's doing this, if that suffices to hold a lender liable, surely it should hold a corporate... an affiliated corporation liable.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: For several reasons not so, Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Kenneth Steven Geller
context.text: First of all, it's not participation in the management of a subsidiary.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --Well, we are relying on effects to the extent that they are elements of the crime.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: That is, here it's not simply the case that the money-laundering did facilitate the drug-trafficking activities.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: It's the case that in order to obtain a conviction for money-laundering, we would have to show that the funds were--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Use Justice Kennedy's example with counterfeiting.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Use Justice Kennedy's example with counterfeiting.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: It's the case that in order to obtain a conviction for money-laundering, we would have to show that the funds were--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Use Justice Kennedy's example with counterfeiting.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: --I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Use Justice Kennedy's example with counterfeiting.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I mean, you have the person passing the $10 bill, but the bill was counterfeited in Arizona.

context.speaker: Malcolm L. Stewart
context.text: I think that probably would fall under our theory, although I think that's a harder case, because the harm in that case would be felt where the counterfeit bill was passed, and not where the bills were manufactured.

context.speaker: John W. Rogers
context.text: --Thank you, Your Honor, and you are absolutely correct.

context.speaker: John W. Rogers
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: John W. Rogers
context.text: In a situation when you're an accessory after the fact--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And this is a case in which Justice Scalia may even agree with you.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: John W. Rogers
context.text: --If you are an accessory after the fact you aren't legally liable for the principals.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: As the Court made clear in Richards, the question is whether the officers' reasonable suspicion at the time they make the entry.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: There may be circumstances that dissipate that reasonable suspicion if the officers have gone to the magistrate, the magistrate authorizes a no-knock entry, and what the Court made clear in Richards is that if those circumstances dissipate the reasonable suspicion, it would not be reasonable for the officers to forego knocking and announcing, notwithstanding that the warrant contained a no-knock clause.

context.speaker: David C. Frederick
context.text: As the Court made clear in Richards, reasonable suspicion is the standard by which to judge foregoing with knocking and announcing.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Mr. Frederick, may I go back to the question that was... I think Justice O'Connor asked you, and that is, you said that there could be a Fourth Amendment control of excessive force.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: What would be the implementation of that?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Suppose the agents here had come in like gangbusters and destroyed everything in their path, and also picked up some incriminating evidence, what would be the consequences?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Dreeben, can I ask you this.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: There's a brief filed by an amicus, a group of social scientists who say that, if properly conducted, these tests are accurate about 90 percent of the time.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Now, I don't know whether you would accept that, or you would say that's probably wrong, but assume that's correct, and if there are proper safeguards given and all the rest, what would your position be?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Even if it was 100 percent accurate, would you still say, along the argument you're making to Justice Ginsburg, this still should be excluded?

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: I think, Justice Stevens, that it has a drawback from the point of view of courtroom evidence that justifies its exclusion even on the assumption--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: What... under what authority did the President adopt the rule?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: What is the provision that says the President may adopt these evidentiary rules?

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --The President is delegated authority under Article 36 of the U.C.M.J., which is reprinted in footnote 2 on page 5 of our principal brief, and it says that pretrial, trial, and post trial procedures, including modes of proof, may be prescribed by the President by regulations which, so far as he considers practicable, apply principles of law and the rules of evidence generally recognized in a trial of criminal cases in the United States district courts.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Getting back to your colloquy with Justice O'Connor just a moment ago, I think perhaps the Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces might have taken a different view if the Government had sought to introduce the polygraph test, because they seem to base their constitutional decision on the defendant's right to call witnesses in his favor.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: That is absolutely right, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: This was not a two-way-street decision.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Justice Ginsburg, I wouldn't want to disparage the ability of the courts martial members to understand and deal appropriately with scientific evidence, but it is still true that the military conducts an inordinate number of court martial proceedings around the world.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: These proceedings in which, under Daubert, litigants have attempted to admit polygraph evidence usually involve extensive evidentiary hearings back and forth with experts testifying at great length about the supposed merits of the polygraph while other experts come forward and testify about the demerits of the polygraph.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: One recent hearing that was carried out under the Court of Appeals for the Armed Forces decision in Scheffer took 3 days.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, it seems to me you're somewhat deflecting the thrust of Justice Ginsburg's question, and I notice this in your brief, too.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You talk about danger of confusion of the jury.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The military rules allow conclusions of experts on the very premise that military juries are somewhat more sophisticated than most juries.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: My point is the different one, in that polygraph evidence simply doesn't have a history of use in the civilian courts in this country.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: It is in an experimental phase in the Federal courts.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: Massachusetts, which had a 15--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, that may be true, but it doesn't go to the point of the differences in the trier of fact Justice Ginsburg was referring to.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: --The triers of fact may or may not be superior in the military, but the point is that this particular form of evidence, unlike most other forms of evidence, doesn't have a track record.

context.speaker: Michael R. Dreeben
context.text: In fact--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: It's the same government examiner that has given the polygraph.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And there is an inculpatory result.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And the government says, fine.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: As Justice O'Connor suggested, this is a two-way street, and we're going to use it.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: He gets on the stand.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: We're going to say, he's a liar, and here's the polygraph to prove it.

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: Well, Your Honor, I... I would think that the... the... whether or not it's a sea change is going to depend on how narrowly or broadly this Court chooses to view this.

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: Because if you look at it from a standpoint of a polygrapher being someone who has specialized expertise in judging credibility, and look at the others as their specialized expertise in perhaps treating children or victims, there could be differentiations made.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Yet... but your point in... in response to some of the questions, Ms. Sheffield, has been, you know, we don't ask that it be admitted, we just ask that it be submitted to a judge to decide.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But it seems to me, following up on Justice Souter's question, you could then call into question all of the hearsay rule.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In other words, don't exclude hearsay that... it doesn't come within the traditional exception, but if it has a lot of... it seems reliable, put people on the stand and let the judge decide whether it should come in.

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: Well, Your Honor, I'm glad... I'm glad you mentioned the hearsay, because the thing with the other evidentiary rules, designed to ensure reliability and other reasons, all of them have exceptions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I think you should remember it was a 5 to 4 decision.

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Really, the... the... the key difference between... between all of these... all of these other rules of admissibility and... is what Justice Souter was inquiring into.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And that is, leaping over, into... into this new field of... of accepting evidence on whether... whether the defendant is lying here, today, in this trial, on this fact.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: And that's... that's... if... if polygraphs are really that good, you know, 90 percent accurate, what do you think the accuracy of juries is?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, of course, they... they weren't purporting to be experts, reaching a conclusion as to credibility?

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: No, Your Honor, they were not.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: All right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Are there other instances in which experts, as Justice Stevens indicated, psychologists or psych... psychiatrists, are called to... to testify about credibility?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Does this ever happen in... in State proceedings?

context.speaker: Kim L. Sheffield
context.text: Your Honor, I'm not familiar with State proceedings enough to answer that.

Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.case_name: Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. Schacht
Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 20, 1998

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: The result might be the same, but as a matter of discretion, leaving intact the vital differences between jurisdictional analysis, discretionary analysis, Eleventh Amendment immunity analysis.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Then you're changing the answer to the question.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Originally you said, no, no, we're saying Federal court.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The only thing you can do with the State is dismiss it, not remand, and now I think in response to Justice Breyer's question, you're kind of saying, well, maybe not.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Maybe there's discretion to remand.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: But you have no discretion unless you have authority in the first place.

Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.speaker: Justice Souter
Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.case_name: Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. Schacht
Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 20, 1998

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That's the case against them, and so far as the case against them is concerned, isn't subject matter jurisdiction lost once the Eleventh Amendment defense is raised?

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: --I don't believe so, Your Honor, because claims within an action are not parceled out in that fashion.

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: I believe the--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, you just agreed... I thought you just agreed with Justice Breyer that they could be parceled out in that fashion, because we can split the claims against the individuals, the individual responsibility claims from the Government claims, so you're parceling them out.

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: --When we get to the discretionary issue, far from the jurisdictional issue.

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: In other words, when we're looking at jurisdiction to begin with--

Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.speaker: Justice Ginsburg
Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.case_name: Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. Schacht
Wisconsin Department of Corrections v. S.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 20, 1998

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: --I don't believe that's the result.

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: We are asking that a Federal court look at those issues and resolve them.

context.speaker: Richard Briles Moriarty
context.text: If, in fact, it's a dismissal without prejudice--

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
